title: Protocol to access unknown flanking DNA sequences using Wristwatch-PCR for genome-walking
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
PCR procedures
Timing: 9 h
The WW-PCR implements retrieving an unknown DNA using the partial overlap among three WWPs. A WW-PCR comprises three consecutive nested amplification reactions. And parallel WW-PCRs involve permutations of the WWPs. This section details the principle and operations of WW-PCR.
Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1] presents the rationale and process of WW-PCR. For convenience and clarity, only employ the permutation WWP1-WWP2-WWP3 to illustrate WW-PCR.

Figure 1. Overview of wristwatch PCR
GSP1, GSP2, and GSP3: gene-specific primers for primary, secondary, and tertiary PCRs, respectively; WWP1, WWP2, and WWP3: wristwatch primers for primary, secondary, and tertiary PCRs, respectively; thin solid line: known sequence; thin dotted line: unknown sequence; colorful thick line: primer complement; HSC: high-stringency cycle; LSC: low-stringency cycle; and RSC: reduced-stringency cycle. Only WWP permutation WWP1-WWP2-WWP3 is presented here to illustrate wristwatch PCR. Permutate the three WWPs into three combinations (Table 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl2]).

Note: A WWP permutation is shown in the same column.
Critical: Each walking experiment includes three parallel sets of WW-PCRs, performed by the three WWP permutations individually pairing with the GSP set. Each WW-PCR set consists of three successive rounds of nested PCRs, executed by the WWPs and GSP in the same row.
Primary WW-PCR.
Assemble PCR reaction components into a 0.2 mL thin-walled PCR tube on ice.
table:files/protocols_protocol_2374_9.csv
Note: Keep all the involved reagents on ice. Use a genomic DNA as template.
Slightly pipet 2–3 times to mix the contents.
Centrifuge at 4,000 × g for 10 s to gather the mixture at the bottom.
Transfer the tube to the programmed thermal cycler and run PCR.
table:files/protocols_protocol_2374_10.csv
Place the reacted solution on ice.

Pipet 1 μL the solution as template of the secondary PCR.
Keep the rest solution at −20°C until agarose gel electrophoresis.
Secondary PCR.
Assemble PCR reaction components into a 0.2 mL PCR tube on ice.

Note: Keep all the involved reagents on ice. Use the primary product as template.
Slightly pipet 2–3 times to mix the contents.
Centrifuge at 4,000 × g for 10 s to gather the mixture at the bottom.
Transfer the tube to the programmed thermal cycler and run PCR.

Place the reacted solution on ice.
Pipet 1 μL the solution as template of the tertiary PCR.
Keep the rest solution at −20°C until agarose gel electrophoresis.
Tertiary PCR.
Assemble PCR reaction components into a 0.2 mL PCR tube on ice.

Note: Keep all the involved reagents on ice. Use the secondary product as template.
Slightly pipet 2–3 times to mix the contents.
Centrifuge at 4,000 × g for 10 s to gather the mixture at the bottom.
Transfer the solution to the programmed thermal cycler and run PCR.

Keep the solution at −20°C until agarose gel electrophoresis.
Pause point: Store the PCR samples at −20°C if the next step is not immediately followed.
Agarose gel electrophoresis and DNA extraction
Timing: Half a day
This step describes how to perform agarose gel electrophoresis and the followed recovery of amplicons.
Agarose gel electrophoresis.
Mix 5 μL PCR reaction solution with 1 μL 6 × loading buffer.
Load the mixture into agarose gel well.
Set the DYY-6C electrophoresis apparatus with voltage of 5 V/cm (30 cm long).
Carry out electrophoresis for 30 min.
Visualize DNA products by the ChemiDoc XRS+ imaging system.
PCR product extraction.
Extract PCR product using the TAKARA agarose gel DNA extraction kit Ver. 4.0.
Measure DNA concentration.

Pause point: Store the PCR samples at −20°C if the next step is not immediately followed.
T-cloning and sequencing
Timing: 5–6 days
This step describes cloning and sequencing of a recovered amplicon.
DNA ligation.
Assemble ligation components into a 0.2 mL PCR tube on ice.
table:files/protocols_protocol_2374_15.csv
Note: Keep all the involved reagents on ice.
Incubate at 16°C for 30 min.
DNA transformation.
Add the ligation solution into 100 μL competent cells of E. coli DH5α and gently mix.
Place on ice for 30 min.
Heat shock for 60 s, and immediately place on ice for 90 s.
Add 900 μL antibiotic-free LB broth.
Incubate at 37°C and 50 rpm for 40 min.
Plate 100 μL the broth onto LB agar plate containing 100 μg/mL ampicillin.
Culture at 37°C for 12–16 h.
Validation with colony PCR.
Assemble master mixture for PCRs on ice.
Critical: Prepare 220 μL of the master mixture to ensure sufficient volume for 10 PCRs (20 μL/tube).
table:files/protocols_protocol_2374_16.csv
Slightly pipet 5–6 times to fully mix the contents.
Centrifuge at 4,000 × g for 10 s to gather the mixture at the bottom.
Add 20 μL aliquots of the master mixture into 10 PCR tubes.
Transfer some cells with a sterile toothpick from a bacterial colony to a PCR tube.
Place the tubes in the programmed thermocycler and run PCR.
table:files/protocols_protocol_2374_17.csv
Detect the PCR products with agarose gel electrophoresis.
Select positive transformants.
Pause point: Store the PCR samples at −20°C if the sequencing step is not immediately followed.
Sequencing.
Inoculate a positive colony to LB broth containing 100 μg/mL ampicillin.
Culture at 37°C and 200 rpm for around 18 h.
Extract plasmids from the culture using the Sangon Sanprep column plasmid mini-preps kit.
Sequence the inserted fragment with the M13 primers.

Pause point: Send the plasmids to the Sangon Biotech Co., Ltd. for sequencing.
Align and analyze the sequences.
Note: Conduct sequence alignment and analysis using the “By Cluster W Method” function of MegAlign tool in the Lasergene software.
